Comment: USCIS has been known to take green cards at borders and yet let people in. At that point you have to deal with the bureaucracy to learn what the issue is and what can be done. This also happens at citizenship or green card renewal application time.   Needless to say the process isn't clear and all kinds of horror stories can occur. Like if your citizenship application is rejected because of the above legal issue, what then? You sit on it till next green card renewal time then????   Having gone thru green card then citizenship I'll be honest to say that it's not the time to FAFO. It may have been 30 years ago when information was scant and computers didn't talk to each other. Today you get cited for weeds in your yard by the HOA and it will show up on some database in a few days.   The stack of papers i had to collect to document my only driving infraction in two decades (expired plate by 2 days, diversion, expunged but not really) was bigger than the citizenship application itself.

Author: AlphaGoldblum

Comment: > The drug crime was committed in 2011  Short answer, ICE has discretion.  A drug offense is permanently disqualifying for naturalization *and* deportable.  You can be a war hero with a Medal of Honor, but you'll still fail the statutory good moral character test under immigration law and you'll never be allowed to become a citizen. However, that doesn't stop you from being able to renew your Green Card. The only thing a letter from ICE might say is that they're not pursuing deportation at this time because for whatever reason, they decided you were not a priority.  Maybe you have that Medal of Honor, or maybe you owe child support.  In either case ICE might decide that it's more convenient to let you stay for a while.  But right now, you're nothing more than a tick mark for their deportation quota.  TL&DR: US immigration laws are a Kafkaesque nightmare.  As are federal drug laws.

Comment: He kind of shifted over the years, frankly. It's notable that Starship Troopers was published in 1959 and most of his more libertarian, free-love stuff was published later - Stranger in a Strange Land was 1961, but frankly, some of the really late stuff like To Sail Beyond the Sunset get seriously weird.   And then you toss in stuff like For Us, the Living, which was written in the thirties but published posthumously and explores a ficitonalized society where universal basic income exists and people don't need to work if they don't have to.  Heinlein is one of my favorite science fiction authors from that era, despite the numorous criticisms you can make about his book, and frankly, the man was just *complicated* and doesn't really slot neatly into any one political philosophy.
Author: lothlin

Comment: And green card aka not a us citizen.    A Green Card, formally known as a Permanent Resident Card, is generally valid for 10 years. However, there are exceptions, including conditional Green Cards that are valid for 2 years. Additionally, there's a process to replace or renew a Green Card, and USCIS (U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services) may offer extensions during the replacement process.   So yeah looks like they said no to renewal because of the felony.  Answer the question though.  Do you think people who commit felonies in the usa should be rewarded with citizenship?
